title: Anorexia in children as young as eight doubles in past decade
text:
The figures are fuelling calls for earlier treatment (Picture: Getty Images/iStockphoto)

Children are developing anorexia nervosa much younger than researchers previously thought, a study suggests.

The number of patients aged eight to 12 diagnosed with the eating disorder has doubled in the past decade, fuelling calls for earlier interventions and treatment.

In that same age group, the rate of sufferers being hospitalised or placed in special clinics rose from approximately 1.5/100,000 to 3.2/100,000 between 2006 and 2015.

This rose to 2.1/100,000 in 2006 when other eating disorders that may now be diagnosed as anorexia were included.

The data was drawn from monthly records, submitted by specialist psychiatrists to the Child and Adolescent Psychiatry Surveillance System in the UK and Ireland for a period of eight months in 2015.

More and more children as young as eight are being affected by the disorder (Picture: Getty Images)

It found 305 new cases of the mental health condition had been diagnosed.

Based on the figures, published in the BMJ Open Journal, researchers calculated an annual incidence rate of 26/100,000 for girls and 2/100,000 for boys.

This results in an overall rate of 14 new cases for every 100,000 child and teenager aged eight to 17.

Young women account for 91 per cent of cases, while 70 per cent of sufferers are from England and 92 per cent are white.

The rate of cases rose steadily with age but substantially dropped by half at the age of 17.

Diagnoses peaked for girls at 15 and for boys at 16.

Young women account for 91 per cent of cases (Picture: Universal Images Group/Getty Images)

Calculations indicate a rate of 4/100,000 11-year-old patients and 12/100,000 for children aged 12.

Despite evidence cases are on the rise, the study’s authors, from universities across the UK and Ireland, were unable to pinpoint what is causing the illness.

Health economics professor at Kings College London Sarah Byford said this is part of a larger study on the cost effectiveness of treating eating disorders in children and adolescents.

She said: ‘The big message that needs to be put out is that it may be the case that children and adolescents are suffering more from anorexia nervosa.

‘What may be the case is that we’ve simply got better at identifying it.

‘The media has played a big part in allowing parents and schools to identify the signs of anorexia nervosa.

‘It’s being recognised earlier and earlier. This can only be a good thing because it means that doctors can treat it as soon as possible.’

Researchers encouraged service providers and commissioners to ‘consider the evidence to suggest an increase in the number of new cases in younger children’.

description: Research published in the BMJ Open Journal suggests children in the UK are developing anorexia nervosa much younger than previously thought.
